blurb.text: Moderator: So I want to welcome everyone to Session 17, How Connected Vehicles Can Improve the Safety and Efficiency of the Urban Arterial Streets. As I mentioned, we have a very experienced panel here. We have Valerie Briggs, Ralph Robinson, Dave Miller

and John Fisher, whom I'll introduce shortly individually. The Connected Vehicle Program is entering its seventh year of development. I think there's a critical milestone ahead of us in 2013, when NITSA (ph) will be considering a regulatory decision to mandate DSRC radios in the new vehicles that come off the line. This is an important milestone, and the program has been around under three different

leaders at the US DOT. We've made progress under every one of these, but I think since I've been on the program, this is a real line in the sand. This is very stabilising. It is something you can put your arms around. I recall when I went down and gave a speech at the NACE (ph), it's the National Association of County Engineers meeting. George Webb, who's in the audience here, invited me down. And

I talked about this program. And of course these folks are dealing with some pretty day to day issues, and I don't think they were too interested in hearing about the Connected Vehicle Program until I said in 2013 there will be a regulatory decision. And 50 people in the room their heads popped up and attention was riveted from that point on.
So let's move on here. I guess there's a, from (inaudible)'s point of view, we have a strong belief

that this program offers very substantial benefits, both in safety and mobility, and we don't see anything else on the horizon that competes with this or offers us the alternative that this program does. So we've invested a lot of ourselves into it, and I've personally worked with most of these people up on the panel for several years. And I've got a lot of hope and expectations for the program.
So as we

move on into the panel discussion, what I will do is I will introduce each of the speakers, and we'll hold the questions or conversation until the end, because I'd like to get as much participation from everybody as we possibly can.
So we'll begin with Valerie Briggs. Valerie works at the US DOT Joint Program office. She is a team lead in knowledge and policy transfer. Prior to that she worked at ASHTO (ph). She was the operations

engineer. She made a big impact on some of our committees, particularly the sub-committee on Systems Operation and Management, where there is a lot of interest in this connected vehicle. And Valerie was in charge of hundreds of people that attended those meetings, because of her leadership. So with that please welcome Valerie Briggs.
Valerie Briggs: Well, thank you Jim. I don't

know that I'm in charge of hundreds of people, but this is a big program at the US Department of Transportation, and just to tell you a little bit more about it, our current efforts stem from a strategic research plan that the department developed for ITS in 2010. and the theme of the ITS research over the next five years is indeed focused on connected vehicles, and connected vehicles of all types - buses, trucks, light passenger vehicles, even bicycles,

motorcycles and pedestrians and transit vehicles. So it is a multi-modal program that was developed by seven different modes within the Department with also significant stakeholder involvement from many of you through some public meetings. We now have over 80 people in the Department working in some way on connected vehicles, so that just tells you what a major focus it is

for the US Department of Transportation. This just is meant to show you the concept that what we're trying to develop in conjunction with our partners at the state and local government and the vehicle manufacturers is the ability to have interoperable communications among all vehicle types with infrastructure elements, as well as with other vehicles and with devices that are used by passengers. And so this is the challenge before us.
What does this mean

for city streets? This is our city streetscape. This means that any vehicle will be able to broadcast information about itself to other vehicles and travellers in the system around them. So for instance, if technology is built into the vehicle electronics, it is able to broadcast a whole bunch of information. That's what you see by that lower left is the type of information that you can get off of a vehicle today if you have access to the vehicle electronics. And

it goes far beyond heading and speed, to things like windshield wiper status and whether antilock braking systems are on, which could tell traffic engineers where there might be slippery road surfaces. And so this kind of information is really valuable for a number of purposes. Also of course the ability to get probe data from all equipped vehicles in the system for travel information purposes and the other capability

that transportation professionals are particularly interested in is the ability to broadcast messages into a vehicle. So perhaps in future instead of maintaining dynamic message signs, you'll be able to broadcast messages directly to vehicles in a specific vicinity. This is the other advantage. What we're trying to do is enable broadcasting of location specific information. So instead of just general broadcast about traffic congestion in certain parts of a city,

you could broadcast to vehicles at a specific intersection or within a specific corridor about transportation conditions. So it gives a lot of capabilities that traffic managers may not have today.
For pedestrians, pedestrian safety statistics are, there are increasing pedestrian fatalities and so this is of great concern to us. The pedestrian may be able to have a handheld device that's connected to the system that allows broadcasting

of his or her location, to tell vehicles around them that they, not to hit them. Also you could do quite a bit with transit and commercial fleets. Many of the same applications that are available today could be provided perhaps more cheaply through a ubiquitous technology. And you could also tell a lot more information about things like how many passengers are on a bus, as well as whether the bus is on time, things like that. So what we're

trying to do is provide an ability to do all of this through a common set of standards and technology that allows interaction among all vehicle types.
One of the major reasons that US DOT is interested in this technology and set of applications is for safety. Safety is our number one priority and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has recently done an analysis that shows that connected vehicle technology could potentially address 80 percent of the causes

of crashes. Now we don't know how effective the technology will be at addressing these crashes. That's why it's a research program and we're doing research, but it has huge potential to reduce crashes on our roadways. What we're focusing on now is the ability to provide driver advisories and warnings of hazardous situations. So if a car is about to get into a crash - if you're about to run a red light, if there's a queue stopped ahead, 00:08 08 if there's a slippery road surface, things like that, or if there is a vehicle around a curve that you may not see - so what we're focusing on is giving the driver information about hazards.
Our research program is divided into application areas focused on developing applications for safety, mobility and the environment, and then we're also doing underlying research on the enabling technology - things like systems engineering, certification,

standards development, things like that, and human factors research to make sure what we're doing is safe within a vehicle and not causing distractions. And then the area that I work on is the policy research - how do we make this happen? How do we address the institutional challenges?
I'm just going to step you through how we are looking at this problem and how we hope that we will go from a research initiative into a deployed state. So the next few slides 00:09 07 kind of tell our philosophy and our research strategy for getting us from where we are today to a deployed state.
We are focusing on first enabling vehicle to vehicle communications for safety applications. That's where you get the major safety benefits, and we also recognise the challenges with deploying infrastructure, as I'm sure you all are thinking in your mind, how would infrastructure be deployed. So we're focusing

first on enabling technology in vehicles and the applications that rely on vehicle to vehicle communications. So we're focusing on that core set of applications, on proving the benefits of these applications, developing the driver interfaces that are safe, developing globally harmonised standards with our partners around the world, assessing the security issues so that people can't hack into a vehicle, and then enabling interoperability of devices and preparing for the NITSA

agency decision. One thing I will note is that NITSA hasn't said they're making a regulatory decision in 2013. They've said that they will make a decision about whether the research has progressed to a stage that they feel that something should be done to encourage the application of the technology. So that could be a regulatory decision, or it could be something else.
We want to demonstrate these safety capabilities, and our major near term activity is the safety

pilot road test. It is a major road test taking place this year through 2013 involving multiple vehicle types in a real world environment. So we'll be testing both fully integrated, so systems (inaudible) vehicle electronics, as well as testing the ability for after market devices to provide benefits. We will also be testing prototype security mechanisms and certification processes.
There are a number of goals of the safety pilot. I

won't necessarily read all of these but of course our main goal is to help develop the applications and test them and to do benefits assessment to determine whether these applications are successful at preventing crashes, as well as to create public awareness and determine driver acceptance of the technologies.
We do have a number of test environments out there already that are available for people to use if they have ideas that they want to test for applications. We have a test environment

existing in Michigan as well as California, and New York also has a test bed, and we are also in the process of defining a new system architecture. And in the future at least the Michigan test bed will be upgraded to fit the new system architecture once it's developed. And this timeline just shows our schedule for the architecture development. A number of you have provided inputs on that, and we will continue to be reaching out to you for input on

the development of that architecture. We're currently at finishing up the concept of operations and will be sharing that with you and moving into the system requirements development.
The fourth step of course is to build the safety, mobility and environmental applications and to test those. And I've talked quite a bit about the safety application. The safety applications of course have to be very controlled because they do rely on vehicle electronics. So

you don't want anyone developing applications. On the other hand mobility and environmental applications are something that really should be in the public domain, open for development by anyone. And so our focus there is really creating an environment where multiple developers can contribute to application development. So we are establishing data sets that developers can use as well as an open data environment that would allow development of applications and sharing of software among developers, so an open source environment

for software development.
We also went through a pretty extensive exercise last year to identify a set of public sector applications that we would focus on along with our partners, and the handout that you have is talking a little bit about that process and what applications we expect to focus on through US DOT research. And so as you can see our focus is going to be on things like arterial data, building an arterial data environment, so applications

for traffic signals, being able to transmit signal phase and timing to vehicles and develop applications around that, as well as freeway data environments, so things like traveller information systems; regional data environments including emergency vehicle applications as well as transit applications; and then corridor environments. Actually I think the emergency vehicle applications are part of core. Anyway, you have the sheet; you can read a little bit more, and there's plenty more information

available on our website if you're interested in these and this program and how those applications will be developed, and getting more involved in the mobility program. It is really designed to involve the community.
So our fifth step, and this is really future, beyond our current set of activities, is building a reference implementation, so reflecting the system architecture and the standards and other processes have to be put in place for this

to work. So looking beyond the research that we're doing now and recognising that additional testing reference implementations will have to be built to test those various applications in the environment.
Regional pilots also stems from, is the next step of those applications after building reference implementations, and we're talking 2014, 2015, future time periods. But we are recognising that there will be a need for additional testing beyond

what we're doing right now.
So this I'm sure is perfectly clear to you, but our stakeholders kept asking us well how does all of this fit together, how do your various research activities fit together? So here's our attempt to show how they all fit together. So it basically shows where we are today. We're focusing on a number of research activities leading up to the safety pilots. So getting applications ready for testing as well as the architecture in good

shape and leading up towards the safety pilot. And then beyond safety pilot a number of activities leading up to the regional pilots for applications testing. And of course our major milestone is that diamond at the top for the NITSA agency decision. But of course it's not the only milestone, the only thing that has to happen in this program for it to be successful.
So it

is a complex program; I hope it will involve all of you. I hope it's something that you're interested in and excited about, but I'm happy to answer any questions that you have. Also we are having, ITE has a Connected Vehicle Task Force, and all of you are welcome to come to the meeting. It's this afternoon at one o'clock in the (inaudible) Rooms. So ITE does support a task force in this area.
I have to do a quick plug for professional capacity

building. Since we're here at ITE, our office does run a professional capacity building program, and we're always looking for opportunities to work with communities such as yours. So if there is a specific need that you have, please come and talk to us. Max Lister (ph) leads that program in our office. And we just put out a new professional capacity building strategic plan, and we also just now put out a new website, and we have a new technology transfer section

on that website as well as an extensive section on our research, describing our research efforts. So I hope you'll visit that and find it useful and give us feedback on what you think. So that's it - thank you.
Moderator: Okay. Ralph Robinson, our next speaker. Ralph is currently with the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute. He's a research scientist there. Prior to his work at UMTRI, Ralph spent many years at Ford Motor

Company. So I really hope you take advantage of his experience during the question and answer period. I've worked with Ralph since 2004 on this program, and he's very very knowledgeable and very very practical. Ralph also was the past President of the VII Consortium, which is a group of auto manufacturers mobilised to participate in the Connected Vehicle Program. So with that, please welcome Ralph Robinson.
Ralph Robinson:

Thank you, Jim. I certainly appreciate Valerie's discussion of the overall program in depth, and there is a lot of activity coming from US DOT, and I think that's really appreciated, because having worked on this program for so long, we're looking to get it accelerated as rapidly as possible. Today I'm going to overview many of the same things that Valerie discussed from the program level, but I want to focus on some of the deployment issues in

moving this thing into the vehicle side, and I'll talk about some of the HMI issues associated with that.
Over many years the vehicle manufacturers have been working on occupant protection, the technology to save the lives and injury of passengers and drivers if an accident occurs. This led to airbag development; this led to front end crashability to safely control the impact, and it led to airbags. We find that the technology is moving so rapidly in electronics

controls that we now have the opportunity to look at situational awareness around vehicles and now provide a potential to avoid crashes in their entirety. This has great opportunity in the transportation business, because it allows removing a lot of the overhead weight and cost associated with the protection technologies. So at some point we will see stronger and lighter cars, but we will see cars that refuse to have accidents. That's the vision that we are all working toward.
Much of

the technology to start down the path of the safety protection and crash avoidance are technologies that you see on some new cars being introduced on the marketplace today, like standalone onboard sensing and warning systems such as lane departure, lane change and emergency braking. These are showing up in a variety of manufacturers and technologies. Obviously as we look near-term, we will see the introduction of RADAR, LIDAR (ph), optical

cameras to provide a lot of situational information around the vehicle so that the vehicle itself can take evasive actions and can take other information and provide it to the driver in the form of weather, bidirectional information to inform the driver of situation information from the streets like signs and so forth.
But wireless connectivity will obviously enable a whole new generation of cooperative safety systems, the ability to share information between all of the cars in the surrounding

area as well as back end transportation operation, is an enormous potential.
What is a connected vehicle? It's (inaudible) information sharing between vehicles in the form of vehicle to vehicle communication or vehicle to infrastructure communication. It identifies immediate crash threat possibility. It shares information with signals and transportation operators. It informs, coordinates and warns of unsafe roadway situations. There is a wide variety of applications. Many of the applications have direct

benefit when it's deployed between that vehicle and an infrastructure, or that vehicle and an adjacent vehicle. However, many of the applications, for V2V, for example, requires a high population of penetration of the technology into the surrounding vehicles. You can imagine, if you're depending on your vehicle to avoid crashing with another one, if they are in communication and sharing information on speed, location and direction, you can coordinate evasive action or provide the appropriate warning

signals. However, if the car next to you is not equipped with wireless connectivity, then you have no information and the system doesn't work. So many applications require a high penetration of deployment to really make this effective and useful.
What is this wireless technology we're talking about? Well, I'm not going into a detailed discussion. It's basically DSRC equipped - dedicated radio communication. It's based on 802-11P Standard

with 75 megabits of bandwidth allocated by FCC, specifically for automotive safety applications. It's a low latency version of - it's like WIFI on steroids, but it has a very low latency connect time and it shares information extremely fast. It connects to back end servers to aggregate information. All the vehicles, for example, in an area, would send information back through a roadside transmitter

and allow that information to be gathered in a back end server. Obviously transportation operation centers can use that for a variety of purposes, but more importantly it can also send information back to the vehicle in the form of alerts, information for roadside, information like signage and so forth. And certainly enhanced by other wireless activities, wireless technologies as well, such as 3G and 4G cellular have many potential applications that expand the capability

of DSRC for these wireless systems, and we'll talk more about that in just a moment.
There are four functional purpose or functions provided by a connected vehicle. First it provides active safeties in a "here I am" messages between vehicles. Every vehicle theoretically would have a transponder sending to the surrounding area the speed, location and direction. So all vehicles then have the potential of knowing where other vehicles are in the neighborhood. That's very important,

so every car perhaps by the 2013 regulation that is being considered, would be enabled by just providing that transponder on new cars, whether it's from the auto manufacturers or whether it comes from Best Buy or your local radio shop. The fact is everybody would be required to have one of these transponders onboard your vehicle. Whether it provides any other services or not, it would at least provide a transmission of speed, location and direction. That means that other vehicles that

have more advanced technology, after market systems, OEM manufactured systems, can use that information now to provide services onboard your individual vehicles. That appears to be a good opportunity to launch the high penetration rate necessary for these systems to work effectively.
Vehicle information communications - the infrastructure sends information to drivers in the form of roadway signage, for example, where incidents may occur on your particular route and other functions like that. But it receives

that information in the same form. Your vehicle transmits your immediate situational information back to back end servers. All of it gets aggregated and it gets retransmitted back to the drivers.
Another additional requirement of the system is provide location based services, particularly you can imagine if a transportation operator wants to send a message to a one square mile area in the location of Telegraph and Lashers (ph) that there is a storm squall in that

area, that information needs to be focused to just that local area. To do that, the system needs to know where the cars are located, which cars are in that area, and which cars are most likely affected. Those services then are based on the location of the car and changes as vehicles obviously move through an area and depending on what services are being provided.
The fourth important piece of the system of course is provide security certificates

to authenticate that your vehicle is truly a valid participant in the system and you're not just a kid on an expressway overpass turning traffic lights red arbitrarily. So it's important that we manage the process of that authentication well.
Privacy is also an important issue. We obviously do not want a system that would allow government agencies to send you tickets at the end of the day because you were driving ten miles an hour over the speed limit. So the system is designed

to prevent that privacy intrusion.
If we look at all the applications, the potential list is hundreds of applications long, and depending on how you define each one with some overlap, the size of that list can change. But the fact is, once the system is in place, it only takes imagination to find all the potential applications and value a system like this can provide, both for safety, convenience and travel efficiency. In this particular representative list,

for example, I tried to differentiate the content that I described earlier. DSRC equipment, which one of these systems require DSRC and which one of these applications can use alternative communication such as 4G. In the second column I indicate which ones require vehicle-to-infrastructure integration, and which ones do not necessarily need communication to the back end servers. And also I list the location based services applications, which require and which do not require LBS.
You

can see the top four representative examples are V2V. They primarily can be driven by the automakers. They can be driven by after market providers of this (inaudible) transponder we spoke about earlier. But it really limits the size of the task to launch the program into production and into use in the field. Many of the applications following can be done by personal providers; it can be done by governments; it can be done by OEMs;

it can be provided by a number of ways.
Originally when we started this discussion back in 2005, the OEMs and US DOT envisioned this big bang deployment. If the US DOT would build, would provide a build out of DSRC on all the intersections around the country, about $20-30 billion dollars was considered chickenfeed at the time. Would OEMs provide the equipment on board to flesh out the entire

system? And we even thought that the system technically could be up and running by 2010. boy, that was a little aggressive, while the serve to focus research activities was found to be entirely unrealistic as well, although I think we all benefited from that early work and discussion, because we had many many industries come to the table collectively to discuss the issues, the technology, the vision, and it was a very formative, active first

couple of years. I thought it was very useful.
One of the problems that when realism sets in of course is the size and complexity of the system. There's 250 million cars on the road today. That equals the number of cell phones in use as well; there's 250 million cell phones, probably half of them here in the room. And also who is involved in this process of implementation - who owns the roads? US DOT certainly has freeways, ASHTO, the 50 states

involved own probably a third perhaps on average of the roads in the country. But there's 3,000 cities, counties and villages that own the rest of the roads. Who is going to maintain these things, build it out? Who's going to coordinate between them? Who provides the training, the maintenance, the overhead, the funding? Where does the governance come from? Has that been defined? Well, there's some ideas along the way but

it's clearly not defined yet. And where are the standards? Well, there's a lot of standards now in place and now being developed and worked on, so that's the good news. However, there's a lot of other standards that still need to be fleshed out. So doubling the size of the existing telecommunication business is a really significant effort that I think is not well understood at the moment.
Rollout's a big problem. Because we have

250 million cars, and if we want all of them equipped with a system, the OEMs only manufacture and produce 15-16-17 million per year, well simple division will tell you it takes 17-20 years to really get all the cars replaced. In 17 to 20 years the technology you started with is already obsolete and will need to be upgraded several times by the time you get to a full deployment. And so is it ever

possible to imagine all cars will have the same application of the same technology at the same time? Hmmm. That's going to be a difficult process to accomplish that. Vehicles take 2-4 years to design, but yet the personal devices are new on the market every six months. Vehicles are owned for 2-10 years between purchases. Obviously you throw away a cell phone in 18 months. There's a real disparity between how the technology is growing much much faster than

new cars are coming to the market. On the other hand you can see car technology is expanding very rapidly as well. The earliest standalone technology, as I mentioned earlier, because they only require an individual car for its operation and use, it's at the freedom of the automaker to bring these technologies forward and be fully useful by the owner of the car, because it does not require cooperation by the car next to you. That cooperation is

when it becomes an industry problem to coordinate information flow between.
Other methods can be used to accelerate the deployment rate. Certainly that's going to be important because we can't use the OEMs to spend 20 years doing it, so therefore how can we move faster? There's a couple ways. Embedded by OEM suppliers, we can take the nav systems today that's in the center console of your vehicle - they're provided by outside suppliers. These

suppliers can bring new updates to navigation systems with new features and functions that augment the navigation with many of thes4e connected vehicle applications. They can be purchased and changed much quicker because there's many suppliers that bring these technologies going in - they can be integrated quickly. So some of the technology can be merged faster.
Retrofitted and upgraded by dealers, same thing. After you purchase a

car, a year down the road, a new technology for connected vehicle happens, you go back to your dealer, they can retrofit and replace existing technology onboard the car with new upgraded technology.
After market devices, you should be able to go to Best Buy and buy again like you do a nav system; you should be able to buy another small device that does signal warning as you approach traffic signals for signal violation. Brought in by the user - many

people use PDAs, cell phones in your car today. That technology, as I mentioned, changes so fast. If that can be brought in as part of the safety application, that's a perfect way to do it.
But all these approaches bring along their own set of problems as well; nothing is free. Usually the kind of devices that show up in the cars today, they're all over the place and the features and functions and

what they do in technology, they change so rapidly it's kind of hard to be state of the art in any one of them. Handheld devices bring a whole social revolution that has just developed in the last five years, for example that didn't exist when we started in 2005 talking about connected vehicle, VII. This whole social revolution is bringing all these problems in the vehicle too for driver distraction. They're okay when you're walking,

riding and sitting, but they're certainly not okay to use at the point of driving. Why? Because they distract the driver.
Four different kinds of impaired driving: driver takes his eyes off the road; hands off the wheel; mind off driving; driver HMI overload; driver biomedical problem. We understand some of the causes of driver distraction, but manage them as part of the problem. When we look at the most recent problem with testing, for example, it

violates three of those distraction rules. The driver takes his eyes off the road, he takes his hands off the wheel to operate small (inaudible) keyboard, and he also takes his mind off the road. Many smart phone applications are coming on the market to help address that with voluntary use. Smart phones will not operate or function when you're driving above 10 miles an hour, for example. And here's a couple

of them; there's many, many more on the marketplace, and there's a lot of creativity going into this personal device manufacturers to find other ways to manage that problem. So help is on the way, but is it going to be in time?
Let's not throw the baby out with the bathwater. If we look at all the ways to constrain or control or not use personal devices in the car, then we give up a lot of emergency service use, points of interest, entertainment,

navigation - a lot of features that do provide the driver with significant comfort and convenience and safety features. The problem - there's a news bulletin for you - portable devices have got these little tiny displays and keyboards and buttons and switches that are hard to operate when you're driving 80 miles an hour, your kids are yelling in the back seat, and you're trying to upgrade the navigation system with a new point of reference because

you just passed the entrance and you decided to go to a different location at Disney World, for example. So there's a problem. The HMI is really a crucial issue. If you're going to bring all this technology into a car, to assist in rolling out this connected vehicle technology faster, we have to manage that HMI issue.
Certainly voice recognition and voice synthesis is going to be an important tool to assist the auto manufacturers in providing a more usable

human interface. All the manufacturers are coming out with new onboard interfaces that allow the driver to communicate hands free with your own personal device. There's some difficulties there, because all device manufacturers have different connectors for smart phones, PDAs - it's really a minefield trying to make them all the same. But that's a whole area of standardisation (inaudible) on the edge but outside of connected vehicle capability to manage

that problem, but nevertheless it's a real problem and the auto manufacturers are working on it today.
So, last slide, Jim. The incompatibilities will have to be resolved using a variety of methods, innovations and HMI standards and government regulations. It's a very complex problem. We're all going to be seeing the effects of that over the next 5-10 years. And in some place in there, out the back end will arrive the connected vehicle system. I think

it's going to begin showing up the benefits that we're seeing the potential. Active safety systems, however, requiring real time interactive control between vehicles using personal devices, may not be reliable enough. In other words bringing your PDA into the car and having it connect to Bluetooth, being the intelligence for many applications for the connected vehicle system may not participate in providing brake control in the form of emergency violation management or

crash avoidance. There's obviously none of reliability in a personal device on how it's mounted in a car and who provides it and so forth, to make that practical or useful.
Approaches using after market upgrades may not be acceptable to the public without government mandates. The bottom line, getting a high national penetration of connected vehicles is going to be very, very difficult to achieve over the long term. Thank you, Jim.
Moderator:

Sir, you covered a lot of ground there. Thank you. So our next speaker is Dave Miller. Dave is an R&D manager at the Siemens ITS in Austin, Texas. Actually I actually just finished a major deployment report for this connected vehicle, and Dave actually did the work for the signal portion where we kind of analysed what it would take to replace the current controllers of the signal system with a fully compatible

DSRC radio. Dave is also the Chair of a major standards effort, the ATC Joint Committee that's managed by ITE NIMA in ASHTO. He's also a member of the task force that will be meeting after that Valerie talked about. So with that, please welcome Dave.
Dave Miller: Okay. Thanks, Jim. I'm going to pick right up where Ralph left off here. I'm going to pick up with some of the use

cases. Most of them are well known and I'm going to go through them quickly and I'm going to give you a little test afterward. I'm going to ask you three questions.
Okay. So collision avoidance - Ralph talked about that in detail. So that's vehicle to vehicle. Signal phase and timing, so this is where like on the Michigan test bed, like Valerie said, you can go to the Michigan test bed. If you something you want to test, you can

get a vehicle - there's a vehicle fleet there - you can get signal phase and timing. One example would be, put signal phase and timing on your navigation screen when the signals are snowed over or fogged or something, instead of going out and trying to heat the signals.
Wireless detection - instead of cutting loops in the street or instead of putting video detection, you have the "here I am"

device in the car, the intersection traffic signal controller listens to them all, calculates the arrival time of all these vehicles coming. The highest priority gets the priority; if there's no emergency vehicles, transit buses or whatever, private vehicle, you get the green light every time. The interesting thing we found out from Michigan test bed is DSRC acquisition distance

is quite good for this application, 300 meters or more, sometimes double that, we've seen. So what that means is the vehicle computer knows what the traffic signal is going to do before the driver does. The driver is going to see this four-second yellow and then dilemma zone, whatever. But long before that the vehicle required the DSRC. So what we put in our software for the last couple of years is

what we call a pre-yellow. We just put that, we set it to zero, and I don't know how many traffic engineers or signal engineers are in the audience, but what it allows you to do is depending on approach speed - if you're going 88 feet per second, 60 miles an hour, whatever - you can take this acquisition distance and start doing some active safety manoeuvres. And we worked with the Active Safety Group with Ford

and camp on some of this stuff. But in actuated control, the old idea was a few years ago, well the signal people, the car guys would say when's the signal going to change and we would say well we don't know; when are you going to get there? Because it's actuated, right? So what we're doing now is if you're going towards the intersection you can now set a pre-yellow term and as soon as we do the acquisition we can start doing the exchange of

data on it. Like we can start giving all of the cars out there that are approaching it a countdown to yellow and a countdown to red, even though it's an actuated intersection, because we know when they're going to arrive. So that was one thing, one very early when we came out of the test bed that that's in standard mainline traffic signal control now, so that's there and ready if you want to start doing predictions.
Another

one is electronic tolling. Electronic tolling is, you're coming from the airport, you go through a gantry and a toll booth and all that. If you have, everybody has a "here I am" device, you just compare a toll zone to the GPS location of the car. You do the billing that way without a gantry.
Emergency vehicle interoperability. In our hurricanes that you have here but you also had in Texas, we had problems with we had lots of volunteer

emergency districts where there were three or four major manufacturers of emergency vehicle emitters, and they're not interoperable with each one. So one thing we're doing is we're taking an onboard unit, leaving in place the third party emitters that are there, but taking that and using the onboard unit to translate the standard message set of 2735 to a roadside unit. So instead of putting up special purpose transponders just for emergency vehicles,

we're just using those as a translator. What that means is when we have a hurricane or widespread emergency everyone is interoperable; all the emergency first responders are all interoperable. So these are some early wins that we've done.
Transit signal priority, this is something we're doing for a major city in Texas where same thing - mobile terminals on the bus. There's always some sort of a different way of doing things for transmitting back. But

what we're doing is we're using an onboard unit as a translator using standard message sets. So what this sort of is going towards is if you have a roadside radio it can perform the function of all these different things, and if you have an onboard unit you can do the functions and then everyone is interoperable.
I live in Austin. We have the university there with 52,000 students on one campus and we ride a lot of bikes. I

ride a lot of bikes. And we're working with some of the professors there on a bicycle safety device. The bicycle carries on onboard unit that transmits the signal. Like I was out Sunday and a bunch of sat in a pack for I don't know how long waiting for a pretimed intersection to change. But you know, your bicycle you can get the light and it broadcasts the warning to drivers that there's a bicycle over

the hill, that sort of a thing. Again, that's something that's done now. I mean we have signal control out there and a lot of other vendors do for bicycle lanes, but this is just another way of doing it.
Vehicle charging station - we make vehicle chargers in Europe. What we're using the onboard unit there for is when you drive up and you take your parking place, the onboard unit tells you the charging station vehicle type, the charging

cycle and how depleted you are, that sort of a thing. Vehicle miles travelled, this is, done a lot of work in Minnesota on this. Instead of collecting money from fuel tax and then getting it back in various proportions, it just collects vehicle miles travelled within taxing district and then does rebate directly back to the taxing district. Parking guidance, same thing. Instead of having all the parking signs

and sensors there would just be a "here I am" device just looks at the cars and looks, knows the spaces so it can guide the car. Parking metering, same thing. Instead of getting out and going to a parking meter when it's hot, standing in line, it just does an automatic metering, says "here I am", the GPS center of my car is right here in the middle of this parking spot; you can bill me.

Parking reservation and enforcement, in downtown Austin when we have a big event down there those parking places are very valuable, so you can reserve your place, go down there and your place is there, or you've already got a ticket because "here I am" - no, you're not supposed to be here, that sort of a thing.
Okay, so the questions are, what do all those have in common? Number one is, they all have an onboard unit, onboard equipment. So you have a "here I am"

device. The "here I am" device says "here I am", this is the GPS location in the center of my vehicle and this is my priority - I'm an emergency or I'm an average driver. The second thing that's common about this, if you look carefully at each one of those as a business case, every single one of those you can do today at a higher cost. Every single one of those has a piece of hardware that does something. You can cut loops in the street or you can put up video detection. Maintaining

loops in the street is more expensive than putting up one roadside unit and doing detection once everybody has an onboard unit. And you can go right down the list. Every single one of those has a piece of special hardware that does something. So there really is a business case there; it's just that the money is spread around so much. So it takes very careful - instead of sitting back and waiting - we have some leading edge customers

that are not waiting for it to be funded, but says well I've got this money now; if I just carefully spend it on the new technologies I already have the budget for and there are some savings to be realised.
So the total cost of ownership, the black at the bottom, are the things that you spend money on; you already have budgets for all that stuff. You have budgets for proprietary emergency transponders. All the districts, like in the

Houston area there's 11 or 12 or 13 emergency districts and they pool their funds and they buy equipment. There's proprietary transit signal transponders, video detection, loop detection, and a big chunk of accident investigations and litigations. Major cities in the United States, some of them have $20-30 million a year budgeted for litigation. So there's lots of money out there; it's just how do we get this all to fund into the right little buckets.
So

if that can be somehow make a business case for using existing fundings for a roadside unit, roadside installation and V2I software apps (ph). So that's a new term we're kind of coming up with, and I'll show you one that we've done already.
So this is in the Harris County, Texas area, and again this has to do with the aftermath of Hurricane Ike; what are we going to do next? The hurricane

came, all the cars went to I-10, every stopped, nobody moved. Don't have evacuation routes, because everybody will follow them, and everybody will be there, and it does not work. So what this is is affordable travel time and speed for wide deployments. And this was funded by ARA (ph) money. But this is sort of the trend of the way we see things going here. This is a piece of research that was funded by RETA

(ph) on a grant. The grant was issued to Texas Transportation Institute, and they did a project. They developed a technology and had it running on a laptop computer, they proved that it worked. And then we licensed the technology and we just turned it into a software app. So the software app runs on a standard traffic signal control. So instead of going out on the KD freeway where we have our multimillion dollar overhead signs and all these tag

readers and everything that do travel times, we're putting out right now 400 intersections of what amounts to nothing more than this little picture down in the corner is a picture of a little shark fin antenna we got from the automotive supplier. And in it we put in three antennas: one for Bluetooth, one for GPS and one for DSRC. So at no additional cost we're going out there, we're putting widespread travel time and all these

intersections are ready for DSRC when we come back and put the radios in later. Okay, so that was done with money that was there.
Another one in the same project is emergency vehicle (inaudible) from 1960. That's a farm to market road that's outside of Bush Airport. So we have 38 intersections there, and again this is emergency response. This is where we had I think 12 different emergency districts. And we have a software

package now that runs under traffic signal control that can handle 19 first responders arriving at any single intersection from six different directions. So north-south, east-west, and maybe a diagonal light rail going through the middle of it; we see some of that; so that's a piece of software. And then what it does is it keeps synchronised the coordination of the cycle, so instead of just handling all these emergency vehicles and keep them

from colliding with each other, which happens quite a bit, it also puts all the traffic flow back together at the end. So that's running on the Seattle Light Rail line and also it's running out there on the FM 1960. What we're doing with that is as we put that in we're again putting in the DSRC infrastructure, so the antennas, the cabling, everything back, so that when we come along later when we have transponders we can drop in there, again

it was all budgeted out of the same budget that the emergency district used to do their equipment on their budget per year.
So I'm going to conclude by saying that the future trends are, and I think the prior speakers said the same thing, there isn't going to be this big lump of money that comes down and gets deployed everywhere. But there is a business case for funding by what I'm calling migration of your existing budget. So

that our first two trips through this, we actually did migrate some money that was destined for some transponders that were non-standard. We migrated it over to V2I technology. We're putting in all the infrastructure for that. And then we're going to have long-term savings in putting them in as software applications instead of hardware on the roadside that you have to maintain forever. Okay, and the second thing is connected vehicle technology will be less expensive

in legacy. We've proved that on these two projects. We can go get off the shelf bids from three or four different vendors. But if we take the research that's out there that's been done, turn it into a software app, charge a license fee that's lower than what the equipment charges to recoup our investment, we can start doing all these applications as software apps, just like your phone. Instead of having it on your phone, it's on your traffic

signal controller.
The next trend is once this is all out there, traffic signal control will be based on arrival time and vehicle priority. All this pre-time stuff, if you have a fully totally congested gridlock system, it's still going to work like it does now - not very well. You're going to have timing in splits and offsets. But if you're the person in the middle of the night or there's a congestion level that's here and you're below that

a preset congestion level, it's just first come first served. So everybody gets the light once they have an onboard unit.
And then the final thing here is that technology will consist of software apps for ATC 5.2 standards controllers. That's what our committee did and that was part of the deployment analysis that was mentioned by Jim. The signals, traffic signals going on the street now signal controllers; NIMA, ASHTO,

Cal Trans being part of ASHTO, and ITE have a joint ballotive (ph) standard now. It's an open Linux platform. You can write software apps or independent traffic signal control. On the ITE website right now you can do a no cost download. But what we did with this Bluetooth travel time was we just put the Bluetooth travel time app on the traffic signal controller and it runs as an independent app. Traffic

signal control doesn't even know about it. It shares an IP address. So that's what I'm thinking are what the trends are going to be, and I think that's all I have.
Moderator: So we're going to continue on with our speakers that are pretty heavily involved in the actual reality of transportation. Our last speaker is John Fisher. He's an assistant - he is the Assistant General Manager at the LA DOT. He's been there quite a few years. He's

in charge of one of the biggest integrated traffic systems in the country. I think you and New York City are probably the ones that are competing. I remember long time ago when I was with Minnesota DOT we were into performance measures, and we invited some folks up from the Los Angeles City DOT to talk to us about performance measures. And we had all kinds of performance measures. And they said, we have one performance measure - it's called throughput. And

I thought boy, that's pretty clarifying, you know. And so with that, John, it's up for you, and let's give John a warm welcome.
John Fisher: Well one of the disadvantages of being the last speaker is I kind of feel you've heard it all. You've heard about the vision of connected vehicle, you've heard about some of the applications. They've gone into the technology and the complexity of putting it all together. So what I hope to

do here is just give maybe a slightly different perspective, and that is the perspective of a local agency that intends on applying this technology. Not just a local agency, but a city, a large city, a large mostly urban city, and a large mostly urban city that has invested heavily already into its advanced traffic management system. So how do we embrace connected vehicle?
I'm kind of reminded, seeing all the colleagues here in the audience here,

of one I ran into yesterday at the exhibit hall, and he saw my speaker button and said, what are you speaking on, and I said oh, connected vehicle. And he just kind of looked quizzically, and I said, you know, intellidrive, VII, vehicle infrastructure integration. And he says oh, is that the name you've finally settled on? And I thought well given the history of the name change, I'm not sure I can say we've settled on it, but certainly that's what we're calling

it now. But what matters, not so much as what you call it but rather how quickly we can develop it, embrace it and deploy it.
So let me go into a little bit about where we're going with connected vehicles, but I need to tell you about the system we have and how this will complement or integrate with that system. As you know, the city of Los Angeles has a population of four million people, about 470 square miles. But we're not just one city; we're

part of, we're the center of a major urbanised area that includes about 10 million people. And one that is unique about Southern California is that you just don't have this city that's the big center and then kind of the suburban less populated area around it. There is medium high density throughout the entire urbanised area, which includes most of the County of Los Angeles, and adjacent Orange County and

adjacent San Diego County. So it's one big dense metropolitan area.
But that's the city of LA by day. We certainly have an active night life and what comes with all that is well, freeway congestion. And when the freeways get congested, because we basically have a freeway network that was for the most part fully mature and developed by the end of the 1960s and the population has grown about 50 percent since that time, some

of that spills over into the city streets, and so we have street congestion. And every year the Texas Transportation Institute puts out a report identifying the most congested areas of the nation, and we're always in the top three. Sometimes we've been number one. For the last couple years I think we're down the list but not far down the list. We're still number two or number three. So congestion is a fact of life in the city

of LA.
So we have congestion to deal with. We also have many special events that occur at the many sports and entertainment venues that we have. This is Dodger Stadium, the Hollywood Bowl that's going to become active within the next two months because of the pleasant weather we have, and you can picnic and watch a concert at the Hollywood Bowl and many other venues.
So in response to that we developed,

a number of years ago, a system called ATSAC, an acronym for Automated Traffic Surveillance and Control. And that has become the platform for our high technology, advanced traffic management, intelligent transportation systems, whatever you want to call it. That's become the platform and the backbone of the system that we've used to monitor and manage traffic in the city.
The way the system works is we have system detection and yes, we still use loop

detectors; they've been the most reliable for us. System detection looks at the count of traffic and the occupancy of traffic to tell us what traffic plans should be automatically implemented. It's a sampling of traffic. We've put in the most modern model 2070, the most capable controllers that are part of that system. We've put in fiberoptic cable that connects the various traffic signal systems throughout the 470 square mile

area of the city that connects with downtown. We connect all of our signals with this fiber, but we also between signals connect them with copper cable. So it's quite an interconnected signal system.
We have a traffic management center into which all this data feeds. And on a second by second basis we sample traffic, look at the amounts of delay and amount of traffic coming in, and automatically the system determines how the signals should be set to manage

that traffic on a split offset and cycle link basis.
With the information coming into the ATSAC center we can look at what's happening in real time. This shows one of the graphics we receive on a sub-system level that shows the center of the square of each intersection, shows the congestion levels based on traffic volume or occupancy. The little rectangle outside of the intersection shows what the signal is doing in real time. So

on a sub-system basis we can see who's got the green and where the congestion is, and we can even look at traffic on an intersection basis once we scale down, and this tells us who's got the green. You can see with that green arrow pointing downward. Who's got the red, with the red T symbols. And the little octagons, that indicates the level of congestion that's measured by our loop. So they're symbolic of our loops basically,

and again we can get vehicle counts and occupancy counts. So we know in real time what's happening. The information up above is the signal timing information.
Supplementing that system is a closed circuit television system. It's not live film video. It's just view only video. So that if our detectors tell us that there's a problem, then we can see maybe the nature of the problem. Is it due to construction, is it due to an accident, is it due to some other

police action or something? That tells us the causes of some of the delays that we may observe. And we put them - you can see here, on our 45-foot sturdy poles with a heavy foundation to avoid vibration so that we get an image that doesn't move around too much. But we also deploy them on top of buildings, and that's mitigation for developers. If they want to put in a high-rise and they have to mitigate their impacts, they may have

to do some intersection improvements, or they may contribute to an ATSAC system, to help us build it. But often we ask them to put a camera on top of their buildings so that we can observe conditions for a couple miles into the distance from that building.
We also supplement our system with some variable message signs that can be used to advise motorists of unusual conditions. This is one we put in the Hollywood

area. We did find that we couldn't just put the standard state highway overhead sign on our city streets; we had quite an adverse backlash from that. So we tried to gussy them up and show the community name. That wins kind of the community support to put these signs in. So that's why we've got the Hollywood name on it and some of the nonessential fancy design of it. And interestingly enough, you know since we're in Walt Disney World area here,

we got our inspiration from Disneyland over in Southern California, because Disney put in a streetscape program on the main streets serving Disneyland and they used very fancy poles; they had the budget to do it. So we were inspired by that and we thought we'd put in decorative VMS signs as well.
But we've evolved beyond just getting information to the controllers in the ATSAC centre so that they can manage

the signals and manage the traffic. We're trying to give information back. So whether it's by the VMS sign when you're really out on the road, or when you're at your home before you enter the road. If you want to know what conditions are like you can go to this website, Traffic and Photo LA City.org and you can see the congestion levels that we are measuring with the loops in the field and decide which route you want to take, because we have a good

grid system. You can take a variety of routes. And then there's a link to the Caltrans, California Department of Transportation System. So you can look at their congestion levels; you can look at the street congestion levels, and decide if you want to take the freeway or city streets to get to your destination. So this is kind of how we then give back to the drivers so that we can hopefully, so that they won't contribute to the congestion.
We

also have used this now for light rail priority and we detect, we've got a light rail system, quite a light rail network that we're building throughout the city. And we're using this to tell us when we should pre-empt the signals - not pre-empt but give priority to light rail vehicles and let them get through so that they get through without delay, but we do it in a safe way. We also are using this for our Metro Rapid Bus System as

we call it. And this is kind of a hybrid system which it isn't light rail, certainly, and it isn't the conventional bus that stops every quarter mile or less. It's the Metro Rapid Bus, which stops every three quarters to a mile. And its far side has platforms in it - I'm sorry - it loads at the curb. And also it gets transit priority. So that when a Metro Rapid Bus is approaching, if it's behind schedule it gets smart

priority. It doesn't get automatic priority, it gets smart priority. And the way we do it is, there's a transponder that's on the bottom of the bus, and we have a special loop that traverses across all lanes, and the bus basically scans in and we know when it arrives. And let's say the headway for this bus is supposed to be 10 minutes and it arrives at 12 minutes later, well it gets priority. But if it arrives

eight minutes later it does not get priority because then you would bunch up the buses and that would not serve the transit patrons very well. So we've used it for that purpose as well, and because we know where the buses are in our network by scanning them in, then we can give back information at the bus zones to let people know when the next bus should arrive.
We're also using this ATSAC system as a test bed for new technology. And one of the applications,

, and we cleverly erased the name of the company that produces this, but they're in the exhibit hall over there - we're experimenting with another type of detector. As I indicated we use loops; we've been using them since the late 60s, and they work well. The loops have worked well, but we're trying this out. I think the jury is still out on this one. It is a wireless detector. It is one that is more easily installed with just

a simple round cut into the roadway, and the dimensions of this device is two inches by three inches by two inches deep, and you can basically drop it in and it communicates wirelessly and gives us information back on counts and occupancy. Why we're interested in this device is it may be able, and again the jury is still out, it may be able to identify the signature of vehicles. And that's important because in a freeway network you can know the speed of traffic

by sampling. There are no stops, other than delay stops. But we have signals, quite a few signals, and we can measure the speed between signals. But what is the overall speed of travel along a route? And with this signature it can tell you when it recognised it here, when it recognised it there, and therefore what is the overall speed. Not just the speed between signals, but speed along a route. And so we've had limited

success with this. We're testing it at our Dodger Stadium and we hope things work out, but again, the jury is still out on this one.
So where do we go now that we've invested so heavily into this type of system, which has served us well, which is the backbone of everything we know about traffic - how do we embrace connected vehicles? And what we want to show is what we think our most immediate applications are. Certainly

there are so many applications as has been discussed here, but what are the most immediate ones that we're looking at? And we're looking at new ways of communicating with the motorist in special situations. Now we've put up static signs, warning signs to warn of any number of things. However, motorists in an urban area are so overwhelmed by regulatory and warning signs, that they kind of tune them out. And so it is hard to connect with the

motorist. So through connected vehicle we hope to better connect with the motorist, and connect with him in a new way, maybe with some sort of broadcast or verbal message that would come into the car.
So let me just show you a few applications of that. Let's consider those occasional applications. School speed limit 25 when children are present going to and from school. We have a lot of elementary schools and middle schools and high schools on

some of our major arterials. It is difficult to get motorists to slow down appropriately to travel at a safe speed, and what is more important than the safety of schoolchildren? So we're hoping to have a broadcast message as they pass that sign that says slow down, you're entering a school zone. A broadcast message that will, they can see it, they can hear it; hopefully they will adhere to it.
Another occasional restriction is we have

a few priority lanes in the city. And those are unusual. They aren't common; they're only in a few special places. And how do you make motorists realise that you've got to be either a bus or a bike or a right turn only vehicle to enter it? You can post the signs, but a lot of people again are overwhelmed with sign clutter. So how can you communicate them? Again, broadcast a message into their car.
How about other unusual or uncommon situations

? If you look at the top picture, that's really a reversible lane operation. It tells you at that time the center lane is for left turns only. But there needs to be a way to communicate this very unusual situation to the motorist. Look at the bottom sign. One part of the sign tells you you can; the other part of the sign tells you you can't. If you want to get to the Interstate 5 freeway you turn right. But

if you're a truck, don't even think about it, because it's a street that's restricted to trucks. So again, some unusual situation, not common; you need to connect and communicate and broadcast in an alternative way to the motorist.
Let's take one other situation. I'm almost done. Construction areas. Our mayor is going to Washington probably once every other week to talk to the Administration about accelerating a program to rebuild our freeways and to build light

rail transit, and some subway transit as well. We approved a half-cent sales tax for 30 years. He wants to talk to the Administration about condensing that into 10 years and getting a loan which the city will guarantee it will pay it back over 30 years. Should that be successful, and it's called Moving America Forward I believe, we will have a lot of construction areas, where we're building the light rail and the subway, and we will need

to communicate to the motorist that this is a special area. Slow down, be aware, there's a lane drop ahead, obey the cone zone. We will need to communicate that to them. These are special situations that motorists often blow off. The other area is where we have adverse geometrics; we've got a tight curve. Here

we show a 20 mile an hour reverse curve and we need to communicate that to the motorist.
So these are just some of the applications that we envision in a more short term time frame that an urban area can use that doesn't substitute for all that we've invested and all that we've developed, but complements that, and we look forward to connected vehicles helping us to connect to motorists. Thank you.
Moderator: Okay. Thank all the panel. We

really covered a lot of territory here. Valerie started out with the big program overview; Ralph kind of gave us the high level view and identified some of the technology, some of the applications, some of the challenges that were faced. Dave went into very specific applications that they have developed and kind of raised my hopes that this is far closer to reality than what I realised. And then John gave us a

view of a very complex system and how all of this stuff will have to be integrated into it in ways that they've begun to migrate forward. So with that, let's open it up for some questions. We've got a great panel here. Yes, sir, number one.
Question/Answer
Question: Okay, I'm going to ask this question and I'm going to ask you for as specific answer as you can, if you've had a chance to think about it. In

the Northeast, in New England, there's been some resistance with greater diffusion of electronic tolls because people are afraid they're going to put tolls up everywhere because they don't have to build a toll plaza. They're afraid that it will morph into VMT layered on top of gas tax on top of the tolls and the amount of money being really painlessly extracted out of people's pockets will increase, almost without people

knowing. Now David, you talked about ways that this technology could be used to painlessly get revenue. How can the public be assured that this will not lead to revenue bloat, many differentials, many diverse sources of revenue, people can't even keep track. And even on my transponder I don't know how much toll is being charged to my account until I get the credit card bill, and it's all mixed in with everything else. How

do we assure the public that this isn't going to result in more money being taken out of their pockets with them almost not knowing?
David Miller: Yeah. There was a very, very good study done by the University of Iowa on that very subject, where they started off I think there were around 2,000 drivers that participated. And it started out with sort of a psychology test. So if I asked everybody in the room how

much did you pay in fuel tax last year, give me an answer? Don't know. So the answer was, from 2,000 drivers, I don't know. What do you think? So they put down what they thought. And it went on and on and on and they finally said okay, we're going to do a pilot project. We're not really collecting revenue from you but we will let you put this device in your car and we'll go through the taxing districts, and we'll

give you either a public, a very detailed bill of where you went, or one that doesn't have much detail. But to make a long story short, in the end everybody decided that privacy wasn't that big a deal. They really, went through the program, that they really liked the more detailed bill so that they could make sure that it was correct, and they did like the idea of rebating their money directly to the person

down the street that works for the city that fixes potholes instead of going some place and getting a fraction of it back on and on and on. So I would encourage you to read that study. That's the best thing I've seen on the subject.
Moderator: Does anybody else have a reaction to the question? Anybody in the audience have a reaction to that question? All right. Well at least you've got a start on where to go for information. Who else has got some

tech because we have ATMS, but it's 2001-2002 technology. So by the time it rolls out it gets really old. And my second question is, what do you do for legacy users? Say I inherit the car from my dad, I don't want to put after market products on it; it's like a 1951 Ford or something like that. How do you put something in there so that you'll detect it? And same thing with legacy thoughts, just the legacy paradigm of cycling offsets. How

comments or some questions that they would like to - yes, sir.
Question: I have two questions. The first question is, given the importance of deployment and penetration rate, if you're saying the policy will be 2013 and then there's a seven to ten year changeover in fleet, and then the local governments, we take forever to deploy infrastructure. Right now UTCS, some of our neighboring jurisdictions are still in 1970s technologies. We think we're high

do you instead of detecting it as an ETA arrival time, right now you still have to cover minimum pedestrian clearances. That kind of puts in coordination cycle lengths. That puts limited applications on how we can use arrival time instead of versus (inaudible) detection.
Moderator: Thank you. So I guess two questions. One was on legacy systems, how do you incorporate this technology into legacy systems

, and the second question if I understood it right, was how do you incorporate this into personal devices like your car, legacy devices?
John Fisher: The system that I showed you was originally developed using the Federal Highway Administration's UTCS program. And we kind of after a few years kind of then developed our own version of that, because we kind of grew it to the point where we knew how to manage it and then we knew how

to develop it. I think the thing is with legacy systems is you have to evolve them and grow them, and that's what we've tried to do, to evolve it to the point where we not only measure traffic, not only respond to traffic, but we give information back to the motorist and we use it as a platform for other things, such as I showed, transit priority and as a test bed for new technology. So I think the thing is not to throw away what you have

but to add on and complement to what you have to embrace the new and developing technology.
Moderator: Okay. Ralph, did you have any observations on the vehicle side that you want to share?
Ralph Robinson: I think I heard 1951 Ford. That's good news. I think the concept, and I'm just throwing out a concept here, the concept is the requirement to participate in this new connected environment may be regulatory and may require

that all cars past 2022 for example have a "here I am" transponder onboard. I'm imagining that the "here I am" transponder might be very simple, contain a GPS device and probably the small size like an existing navigation system, and I imagine the connection to the vehicle might be just an electrical connection to the fuse box or perhaps the cigar lighter or some other way to get power to it. But that should be all that's required. So on your '51 Ford you can

mount it up on top of the cigarette box, the cigarette tray, and mount it and just plug it into the 12 volt device, and now you're compliant with the regulation, but more importantly you're now participating with other cars, because you do broadcast your speed, location and direction to the surrounding vehicles. So I think initial introduction of the system will probably have minimal requirements to retrofit on older cars that do not have cam buses (ph) for example.
Valerie Briggs:

I do feel compelled to step in here. This is no policy, there is no regulation. This is a 2013 milestone to decide whether the research bears promise to go forward with encouraging technology on vehicles. I think all of us recognise that this is a long term problem and a long term challenge. It's not going to be solved overnight. There's will be systems that can be more easily upgraded than others,

both infrastructure systems and vehicle systems, and there will be varying capabilities that are enabled by legacy systems and new systems. So I think those are all complexities that we realise, and just like any system it takes time for transition. So I don't think any of us think that this is going to happen overnight or that it's going to be easy, but I think that we all think it will ultimately happen.
Moderator: Thank you. Next question, yes.
Question:

I have a two part implementation question. The first one is for Ralph. I do know that in 2008 our Metro Link had a severe crash and we had a guardian system put on there with an advanced technology for crash systems and an autopilot thing. Actually the engineer driving the train was texting when the collision occurred. So this technology exists in some applications at certain places, and I was wondering you know, when we do a study or do

something we look at who is using this technology and study it like a literature review for a thesis. You study what's been done and how you can use it, what the glitches were, how can I improve it. Have we looked at other examples that might exist right now and where we're going with it, whatever problems there are?
The second part is for Valerie. I know you're a policymaker. And I wanted to know how we're going to implement this. If we have

the technology available, how are we going to implement it? A lot of times with traffic control devices we engineer it, then we educate the public, and then we enforce it. And I was thinking, if we've already got the technology and we're educating the public that this is going to be what you need to do, have a "here I am" device and it could be a little standalone that you add onto a car, that's all good. But I was thinking if we could have

a policy where it's part of a DMV, a Department of Motor Vehicles, where - because why would people want to purchase this right away? What's the incentive for everyone to try to have one of these onboard and have a "here I am" device? What's going to make someone who doesn't have a lot of money want to purchase the device? So if it's like a smog sticker, let's say. Everyone has to do it to get their registration. So I

was wondering if there's some kind of policy change we could do for that? I'm sorry, that's two questions.
Moderator: Yeah, I guess so, two questions. Ralph, I think what she was saying is there's experiences in the train industry about driver distraction. Is the auto industry looking at anything and how they're using that kind of information, and I guess the second question was for Valerie about ---
Ralph Robinson:

Well I think the first question is, do we do a background study of existing technologies as we start development of new systems, and that is just a standard practice in almost every major research project. You have to do a literature search; you have to understand existing technology and how it gets applied and lessons learned, and all those things are very valuable. Otherwise, without that history lesson we would never move forward nearly as fast. So that's very important. And

the second question was ---
Moderator: I guess to Valerie, it's on policy.
Valerie Briggs: We actually do policy research. We don't make policy in our office. So we are exploring those sorts of questions that you asked. Part of our research program is set up to look at what some of the business models or good ideas that people have for spurring implementation are. But ultimately what we do is we collect those and we

analyse them. We don't decide anything. So those are some good ideas.
Moderator: Okay. Thank you all very much. We're going to wrap it up and go to lunch. Enjoy yourself, have a good day, and let's thank our speakers one more time.
